content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my moderately cautious nature, I would prefer to minimize the risk of losing out on the game rounds. In this scenario, choosing 'R' could potentially leave me with 0$ for several rounds if the opponent chooses 'B'. On the other hand, choosing 'B' will always yield a guaranteed return in all scenarios except when the opponent also chooses 'B', where the return is slightly less than choosing 'R'. Since there are more possible outcomes for choosing 'B' that result in a positive payoff (68 out of 75), I would choose 'B' to maximize my chances of earning a consistent return throughout the game. {B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.
Given my previous choice, I will continue to choose 'B' for the next round as well, since this strategy has consistently provided me with a positive return when my opponent chooses 'R'. {B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent has chosen 'R', I will stick to my initial strategy of choosing 'B'. This choice will result in a positive return for me, while also minimizing the risk of losing out on multiple game rounds due to choosing 'R' and encountering an opponent who consistently chooses 'R' as well. {B}
